STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
January 20, 2022
Caitlin Norton
Catholic Charities West Michigan - GR
40 Jefferson Avenue, SE
Grand Rapids, MI 49503-4304
RE: License #: CB410245705
Catholic Charities West Michigan - GR
40 Jefferson Avenue, SE
Grand Rapids, MI 49503-4304
Dear Ms. Norton:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on January 19,
2022. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
Modified Settlement Agreement (MISEP) requirements, a written corrective action plan is
required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the
MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
5992.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
(231) 342-3721
enclosure
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12209 Orientation and training
(1) An agency shall ensure and document that each social
service worker and each social service supervisor receives not
less than 16 hours of orientation after initial appointment and
before assumption of assigned duties.
One of twelve new employee files reviewed did not contain documentation that
orientation was provided as required.
R 400.12212 Personnel records
(3) (a) A written evaluation of a staff member’s performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months after the
staff member assumes his or her current responsibilities.
Three of twelve new employee files reviewed did not contain documentation that a
written evaluation was completed within 6 months of hire as required.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents as follows:
(b) within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at least
once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
One of eight open foster care files reviewed contained late USPs.
R 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a written
adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family signing an
adoption application and prior to approving a family for
adoption.
4

One of three adoption applicant files reviewed did not contain a completed written
adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family signing the application.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTLABLISHED
12/11/2019 Interim Report, CAP approved 1/17/2020
12/15/2020 Renewal Report, CAP approved 1/13/2021
R 400.12327 Special evaluation
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(a) Submit a special investigation record to the department’s
licensing authority within 5 working days in the manner
prescribed by the department.
(b) Initiate a special evaluation of the foster home as soon as is
indicated, based on the information received, but not later than 7
calendar days after receipt of the information.
(c) Conduct a thorough investigation including all necessary
collateral contacts.
The agency did not submit a special investigation record, initiate, or conduct a
thorough investigation as required after receiving information that a foster home was
in noncompliance of licensing rules.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the
following:
ISEP 6.16 Supervisory oversight
Supervisors shall meet at least monthly with each assigned
worker to review the status and progress of each case on the
worker’s caseload.
One of eight open foster care files reviewed did have documented monthly
supervision with staff as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED (Previously cited under FOM 722-06H)
12/15/2020 Renewal Report, CAP approved 1/13/2021
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
5

FOM 801-03 Medical passports
Initial medical passport
For children entering foster care, the initial medical passport
must be provided within two weeks of the child/youth's
placement date
Updated medical passport
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
Two of eight foster care files reviewed did not have medical passports as required.
File one: Initial medical passport not provided timely. Child was removed on 7/1/2021
and medical passport was provided on 7/29/2021.
File two: Initial medical passport not provided timely. Child was removed on 5/3/2021
and medical passport was provided on 5/20/2021.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
12/11/2019 Interim Report, CAP approved 1/17/2020
12/15/2020 Renewal Report, CAP approved 1/13/2021
FOM 722-08C Foster Care-Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service
Agreement
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate,
including those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker,
supervisor, foster parent, caregiver, any youth aged 14 and
older and in the case of placement agency foster care cases,
the local DHS office designee.
Five of eight foster care files reviewed did not contain all of the required signatures on
the PATP.
File one: Foster parent signature was not obtained timely on 6/28 PATP.
File two: 3/12, 6/10 and 9/8 PATP does not contain youth signature
File three: 5/4 PATP does not contain foster parent signature
File four: 7/30 and 10/28 PATP’s missing required signatures
File five: 6/1 and 8/30 PATP’s missing required signatures
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
12/11/2019 Interim Report, CAP approved 1/17/2020
12/15/2020 Renewal Report, CAP approved1/13/2021
6

FOM 722-06B FTM Documentation
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in MiSACWIS
using the FTM hyperlink within seven business days of the FTM.
Eight of eight foster care files reviewed contained FTM’s without the DHS 1105 or the
DHS 1105 was not uploaded within seven business days.
FOM 722-06H Timely entry of case contacts
The caseworker must enter the required face-to-face
contacts listed below in MISACWIS within five business days
of the contact. This includes attempted and missed face-to-
face contacts.
Five of eight foster care files reviewed contained contacts that were not entered within
five business days.
SRM 200 Fingerprints
Personnel Training
SAT is required to be taken within six months of working in a
position with CW-CHRI access and every two years
thereafter. CPAs are responsible for ensuring that all
personnel with CHRI access completes SAT timely.
One of twenty-two current employee were found to be in non-compliance to timely
certification of Security Awareness Training (SAT).
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
12/15/2020 Renewal Report, CAP approved 1/13/2021
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
The agency was provided technical assistance regarding initiating a special
evaluation when a licensed foster parent refused a home visit as they must allow
access for licensing and foster care purposes.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
The facility did not request consultation during this review.
7

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care, substantiated
child abuse and/or neglect, or substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
The renewal inspection completed on 12/15/2020 with a corrective action plan
approved on 1/13/2021. During the review the agency had eight violations including
R 400.12607 Agency recommendation, R 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation, R
400. 12510 Independent Living contract, R 400.12503 Policy & procedures, R 400.
12502 Program statement, R 400.12413 medical and dental care policy, R 400.
12306 Application request, R 400.12312 Foster parent training, ISEP 6.19
assessment and service plans, ISEP 6.22 Visits-parent and worker, ISEP 6.24 Visits
between siblings, FOM 722-08C PATP signatures, FOM 06B FTM types and
timeframes, FOM 722-08 foster care ISP supervisor approval, FOM 722-06H contact
with children in out of home placement, FOM 722-06H contact with supervisor, FOM
722-08E foster care/juvenile justice action summary, FOM 801 medical passports,
and SRM 200 fingerprinting. This year there were four repeat violations for
fingerprinting, contact with supervisor, PATP signatures, and adoptive family
evaluation.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The assessment reported the agency’s difficulty in meeting requirements during this
review period. The Chief Administrator (CA) stated the previous year CAP was
effective and there are good systems in place, but staff turnover has been
challenging. In addition to staff turnover, the agency struggled somewhat due to
COVID-19. Specifically, it has been difficult due to the number of new staff that would
have benefitted from face-to-face/in office supervision.
The CA indicated the agency has recently implemented the use of training, tracking
via spreadsheets, and close supervisory monitoring to achieve compliance.
Supervision is pulling metrics on a consistent, scheduled basis and staff are
prompted to review the Book of Business after receiving calendar invitations. The
agency has also implemented protected time for staff and quarterly review of the
CAP.
Interviews
Interviews were conducted with four staff via telephone. Staff acknowledged that
there were some challenges related to COVID-19 but, overall, staff felt as though the
agency adapted very well. Staff reported there have also been some challenges
related to being short staffed and felt that more case aids would be helpful. Overall,
staff reported feeling supported by supervision and stressed that supervision is
always available when needed.
8

VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on a regular license.
_________1/19/2022________
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
January 20, 2022
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
